oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Comparison of the efficacy of pradofloxacin to florfenicol plus flunixin or tulathromycin in beef heifers challenged with Mannheimia haemolytica
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tessman, Ronald K.
Kayser, William C.
Cull, Charley A.
Lechtenberg, Kelly F.
Shankamurthy, N.C.
Rani, Shilpa
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: pradofloxacin
florfenicol
flunixin
tulathromycin
bovine respiratory disease
Mannheimia haemolytica
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The efficacy of pradofloxacin was compared to florfenicol plus flunixin or tulathromycin in beef heifers challenged with Mannheimia haemolytica. Ninety-five beef heifers were chal­lenged with M. haemolytica (60 mL inoculum with 5.35×106 CFU/mL) on study day (SD) -1. Seventy-four heifers with signs of bovine respiratory disease (BRD) were randomly allocated to one of 3 treatments. On SD 0, heifers in treatment 1 (n = 25) received 10 mg/kg pradofloxacin, heifers in treatment 2 (n = 25) received 40 mg florfenicol/kg and 2.2 mg flunixin/kg, and heifers in treatment 3 (n = 24) received 2.5 mg/kg tulath­romycin. All treatments were administered once by subcu­taneous route. Following the treatments, mortality, feeding behavior, BRD recurrence treatment and body weights were evaluated. During SDs 0-to14-day post-treatment, 4 heifers in pradofloxacin treatment, 9 heifers in florfenicol plus flunixin treatment and 7 heifers in tulathromycin treatment died or were euthanized due to BRD. Over the 60-days, BRD-related mortality was 10, 15 and 11 animals in the pradofloxacin, florfenicol plus flunixin, and tulathromycin treatments, re­spectively. Heifers in the pradofloxacin treatment had a lower respiratory score on SD 3. Additionally, the pradofloxacin-treated heifers showed significantly longer feeding duration on SDs 1 and 4 (versus florfenicol plus flunixin), significantly higher head down duration SDs 1 and 4 (versus florfenicol plus flunixin), significantly higher feeding frequency on SD 1, and significantly higher dry matter intake (DMI) on SD 1. In con­clusion, pradofloxacin had demonstrably beneficial clinical and feeding behavior outcomes in BRD compared to florfeni­col plus flunixin and tulathromycin.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: The Bovine Practitioner; Vol. 60 No. 1 (2026): ONLINE FIRST; 86-94
